ET.description: Existing browser exploits would function; but they would need some modifications to access certain parts of the vehicle architecture

SE.description: Basic knowledge of browser exploits and information exchange protocols is required

KoIC.description: The attacker would need some knowledge of the information protocols within the vehicle to access the information they target; but otherwise everything is fairly public domain or otherwise easily accessible

WoO.description: Possible anytime the vehicle browser is in use; which could vary from user to user

Eq.description: A simple computer is the only requirement

SubThreats.Description: A web browser within the vehicles network (typically in an infotainment system) is exploited or compromised by an attacker to gain control of the browsing environment

ET.description: Some research time for known exploits and certain aspects of the vehicle architecture is required

SE.description: Knowledge of basic radio interfaces and potential controls is required

KoIC.description: Most of the knowledge for these interfaces are public facing, however certain aspects that an attacker may want to access may be proprietary or otherwise hidden

WoO.description: Unlimited as the surfaces are essentially always in use by the end-user

Eq.description: Depending on the desired affect, either specialized or standard equipment would be required

SubThreats.Description: An attack that targets vulnerabilities in radio-based communication interfaces

ET.description: Creating the removable media exploit is quite quick, having it function as intended within the vehicle requires more research

SE.description: Knowledge of removable media device exploits is required

KoIC.description: The attacker would need to understand if there are any controls in place to prevent this type of attack for it to work

WoO.description: Depending on the attackers relation to the vehicle owner, it may be quite difficult to gain access to the car and insert the removable media

Eq.description: A standard computer and removable media device are all that is needed and is quite readily available

SubThreats.Description: Exploitation of vulnerabilities found in the execution of data from removable media devices. USB drives, SD cards, etc

ET.description: Getting the application approved for the storefront is a major hurdle that will take a long time to overcome; it will then quickly be taken down after user reports as well

SE.description: Knowledge of software engineering, automotive architecture, and validation spoofing for the storefront is required for this attack to function

KoIC.description: In-depth knowledge of a variety of vehicle eco-systems is required for this attack to function

WoO.description: Unlimited as the user only needs to download and execute the application

Eq.description: A standard computer is required to create the application

SubThreats.Description: A software application that is designed to perform malicious activities when installed or executed

ET.description: These types of attacks can happen within the span of an hour

SE.description: Some knowledge is required in order to pass as a legitimate source; but nothing intensive

KoIC.description: specific knowledge surrounding the vehicle is not required for this type of attack

Eq.description: Specialized equipment may be required in order for the attacker to actually obtain the information they are looking for; even if they have the consent of the driver/owner

SubThreats.Description: An attacker deceives or tricks the vehicle owners or users into revealing sensitive information. Sometimes by posing as a legitimate entity or service. This is a type of social engineering attack

ET.description: Malicious parts would need to be created and tested before this attack could be performed

SE.description: Depending on the installation of the part; it could be quite simple or require a bit more experience to perform correctly

KoIC.description: Some knowledge about internal protocols is required for this type of attack to function

WoO.description: Physical access to the vehicle is required; and depending on the context that time window could be incredibly short

Eq.description: A strong understanding of vehicle architecture is required for this attack to work

SubThreats.Description: Making unauthorized alterations or modifications to physical components or systems with the intention of compromising the vehicle or parts of it as a whole.

ET.description: The attacker would need to contribute to the project and then ensure that it went to market

KoIC.description: This should be a non-factor as the attacker would not need to gain access to this information; as the attack dictates they would already have it

WoO.description: The attacker would need to know when certain parts are being designed and become a part of that design team

Eq.description: Equipment needs would be handled by the vendor; so the attacker does not need to make an investment heres

SubThreats.Description: An attacker infiltrates and exploits trusted suppliers or vendors to introduce malicious components or vulnerabilities into the supply chain itself
